A1.name: Estimated Removal Date Exceeds 8 Years from Date Opened
A1.description: The estimated removal date is more than 8 years after the reported date opened.
A1.why_it_matters: Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA), most negative items must be removed from your credit report after 7 years from the date of first delinquency (DOFD). If the removal date is more than 8 years from when the account was opened, this could indicate the account is being improperly aged or the dates are inaccurate.
suggested_evidence: Payment history showing actual delinquency date
Prior credit reports showing different dates

A2.name: Estimated Removal Inconsistent with DOFD + 7 Years
A2.description: The estimated removal date does not align with the Date of First Delinquency plus 7 years.
A2.why_it_matters: The credit reporting time limit is calculated from the Date of First Delinquency (DOFD), not from when a collection agency acquired the debt. If the removal date suggests a different calculation, the debt may have been illegally re-aged to extend how long it stays on your credit report.
suggested_evidence: Prior credit reports with different removal dates
Letters from original creditor about account status

B1.name: Date Opened More Than 24 Months After DOFD
B1.description: The account shows a date opened that is more than 24 months after the DOFD.
B1.why_it_matters: When a collection agency reports a "date opened" that is years after the original delinquency occurred, this is a classic sign of debt re-aging. The reporting period should be based on the ORIGINAL delinquency date with the original creditor, not when a collector opened their file. This practice illegally extends the time negative information appears on your report.
suggested_evidence: Prior credit reports showing original dates
Debt purchase or assignment documents (if obtainable)

B2.name: No DOFD on Collection Account with Recent Open Date
B2.description: A collection account shows no Date of First Delinquency but has a recent open date.
B2.why_it_matters: Collection accounts are required to report the Date of First Delinquency (DOFD) from the original account. When a collection account shows a recent "date opened" but no DOFD, it may be masking the true age of the debt. This makes it impossible to verify whether the debt should still be reported and could constitute re-aging.

C1.name: Inconsistent Removal Dates Across Bureaus
C1.description: Different credit bureaus show materially different removal dates for the same debt.
C1.why_it_matters: The same debt should have the same removal date across all three credit bureaus, as it is based on a single Date of First Delinquency. If bureaus show different removal dates (more than a few months apart), at least one report contains inaccurate information that needs correction.
suggested_evidence: Credit reports from all three bureaus
Prior correspondence with bureaus about this account

D1.name: Account Status vs. Balance Inconsistency
D1.description: The account status indicates it is paid or closed, but a balance is still being reported.
D1.why_it_matters: Reporting a balance on a paid or settled account is a violation of the FCRA requirement to report accurate information. This negatively impacts your debt-to-income ratio and credit score unfairly.
suggested_evidence: Canceled check or bank statement showing final payment

E1.name: Future Date Violation
E1.description: A date is reported that is in the future.
E1.why_it_matters: Credit reports must contain accurate and verifiable information. Dates in the future are physically impossible and indicate a severe lack of data integrity by the furnisher. This often happens during intentional re-aging or due to software glitches, and it is a clear violation of the FCRA.
suggested_evidence: Credit report highlighting the future date

F1.name: Payment Activity Without Balance Reduction
F1.description: Payment activity is recorded but balance remains unchanged or increased.
F1.why_it_matters: When a payment is made, the balance must decrease by at least the payment amount (minus any legitimate interest). If payments are being recorded but the balance is not decreasing, this could indicate misapplication of payments, phantom fees, or fraudulent accounting practices that violate the FDCPA.
suggested_evidence: Payment receipts or bank statements showing payments made
Account statements before and after payment

F2.name: Suspicious Last Activity Date Refresh
F2.description: Last activity date was updated recently on an old debt.
F2.why_it_matters: Debt collectors sometimes "refresh" the last activity date by reporting minor account activity (calls, letters, account reviews) to make old debts appear more recent. This is a re-aging tactic that can reset the clock on how long debt appears on your credit report, violating FCRA provisions.
suggested_evidence: Prior credit reports showing older activity dates
Proof that no legitimate account activity occurred
Call logs or correspondence from collector

G1.name: Excessive Balance Growth on Collection Account
G1.description: Current balance significantly exceeds the original debt amount.
G1.why_it_matters: The FDCPA limits what fees and interest collectors can add to a debt. If the current balance is more than 150% of the original amount, this may indicate illegal fee stacking, unauthorized interest, or fabricated charges. Many states prohibit collectors from adding any fees not explicitly authorized in the original credit agreement.
suggested_evidence: Original account statements showing initial balance
Itemized breakdown of current balance from collector
Original credit agreement showing allowed fees/interest
State laws on collection fee limits

G2.name: Balance Increased After Account Transfer
G2.description: The balance increased when the account was transferred to a new collector.
G2.why_it_matters: When debt is sold or transferred, the balance should remain the same or decrease. Debt buyers typically purchase debts for pennies on the dollar. Any increase in balance at the point of transfer indicates fabricated charges, which is a violation of the FDCPA prohibition against collecting amounts not authorized by the agreement.
suggested_evidence: Credit reports before and after transfer showing balance change
Notice of debt sale or assignment

H1.name: Medical Debt Reported Prematurely
H1.description: Medical collection reported less than 365 days from service date.
H1.why_it_matters: As of 2023, new CFPB rules require that medical debt cannot be reported to credit bureaus until at least one year after the date of service. This waiting period allows time for insurance processing and billing disputes. Medical debt reported before this period is a violation of current credit reporting regulations.
suggested_evidence: Medical bills showing date of service
Any correspondence with medical provider about payment

H2.name: Paid Medical Debt Still Reporting
H2.description: A medical debt that has been paid is still appearing on the credit report.
H2.why_it_matters: Under current regulations, paid medical debts must be removed from credit reports. The three major credit bureaus agreed to remove all paid medical collection debt. If a paid medical account still appears, the furnisher is violating both this agreement and FCRA accuracy requirements.
suggested_evidence: Zero balance statement from provider or collector
Insurance EOB showing claim was paid

H3.name: Medical Debt Under Reporting Threshold
H3.description: Medical debt is below the $500 reporting threshold.
H3.why_it_matters: As of 2023, medical debts under $500 should not appear on credit reports under new credit bureau policies. If a medical collection under this threshold is being reported, it may be in violation of current reporting standards and should be removed upon dispute.
suggested_evidence: Credit report showing the balance amount
Original medical bill showing amount owed
Documentation that this is medical debt

I1.name: Credit Limit Suppression
I1.description: Credit limit reported as zero or equal to balance on revolving account.
I1.why_it_matters: When a creditor reports a $0 credit limit or sets the limit equal to the balance, it artificially inflates your credit utilization ratio to 100%. This tanks your credit score unfairly. Closed accounts should retain their historical credit limit to accurately reflect utilization history.
suggested_evidence: Original account agreement showing credit limit
Prior statements showing higher credit limit
Prior credit reports showing correct limit

I2.name: Collection Account Age Mismatch
I2.description: Collection account date opened differs significantly from original account.
I2.why_it_matters: When debt is transferred to collections, the new account should inherit the original accounts open date for credit history purposes. If the collection agency uses their own acquisition date, it can artificially shorten your credit history length and misrepresent the true age of the debt relationship.
suggested_evidence: Original account statements showing open date
Prior credit reports showing original creditor

J1.name: Zombie Debt Revival
J1.description: Dormant account suddenly shows new reporting activity after years of inactivity.
J1.why_it_matters: When a debt that has been inactive for years suddenly shows new reporting activity, it often indicates the debt was purchased by a new collector who is attempting to "revive" it. This re-aging tactic tries to restart the 7-year reporting clock and is a violation of FCRA. Old debts should naturally fall off, not reappear.
suggested_evidence: Prior credit reports showing the account dormant or not present
Proof that no legitimate new activity occurred

BK1.name: Post-Bankruptcy Balance Reporting
BK1.description: Account shows a balance or delinquent status after a bankruptcy discharge.
BK1.why_it_matters: Once a debt is discharged in bankruptcy, the furnisher MUST report a $0 balance and cannot report it as 'delinquent' or 'charged off'. They should report 'Discharged in Bankruptcy'. Continuing to report a balance is a violation of the bankruptcy discharge injunction and the FCRA.
suggested_evidence: Schedule F showing the debt was included

J2.name: Multiple Collector Waterfall
J2.description: Same debt appears to have been reported by 3+ different collectors.
J2.why_it_matters: When the same debt has been handled by multiple collectors (a "waterfall"), each previous collector should have zeroed out their tradeline. If multiple collectors are reporting the same debt simultaneously, or if the debt keeps reappearing under new names, this multiplies the negative impact and may indicate improper reporting.
suggested_evidence: Credit reports showing multiple entries for same original debt
Original creditor account number on each entry
Correspondence from different collectors about same debt

K1.name: Impossible Delinquency Sequence
K1.description: Payment history shows delinquency pattern that is mathematically impossible.
K1.why_it_matters: Credit reports show payment history as a sequence (e.g., current, 30, 60, 90 days late). A valid sequence must progress logically - you cannot be 90 days late without first being 30 and 60 days late. Sequences that skip stages or show impossible patterns indicate data corruption or manipulation.
suggested_evidence: Credit report showing payment history sequence
Bank statements showing actual payment dates

K2.name: Suspiciously Round Balance
K2.description: Reported balance is an exact round number suggesting estimation or fabrication.
K2.why_it_matters: Real debts rarely end in exact round numbers like $5,000.00 or $10,000.00 due to interest calculations, fees, and partial payments. While not definitive proof of problems, suspiciously round balances on collection accounts may indicate the collector is reporting estimated amounts rather than actual verified balances.
suggested_evidence: Validation of debt showing balance breakdown

K3.name: High Balance Exceeds Credit Limit
K3.description: The reported high balance exceeds the credit limit significantly.
K3.why_it_matters: While some over-limit spending is possible, a high balance that dramatically exceeds the credit limit (by more than 20%) suggests either incorrect data, fee abuse, or manipulation of the account terms. This affects your utilization calculations and may indicate the creditor changed terms without proper notice.
suggested_evidence: Any notices of credit limit changes

K4.name: Date of Last Payment Inconsistency
K4.description: Date of last payment does not align with DOFD and account status timeline.
K4.why_it_matters: The date of last payment should logically precede or closely follow the DOFD. If the last payment date is years after the DOFD, or if payments appear after the account was charged off, this indicates either data errors or potential SOL manipulation (collectors sometimes falsely report payments to restart SOL).
suggested_evidence: Bank statements showing actual last payment

K5.name: Minimum Payment Trap Indicator
K5.description: Account shows pattern of minimum payments with balance increases over time.
K5.why_it_matters: While not necessarily a reporting error, this pattern indicates the consumer may be trapped in a cycle where minimum payments do not cover interest, causing the balance to grow despite regular payments. This can be a sign of predatory lending practices that may be challengeable under state consumer protection laws.

S1.name: Debt May Be Beyond Statute of Limitations
S1.description: The debt appears to be older than the state statute of limitations for legal collection.
S1.why_it_matters: Every state has a "statute of limitations" - a time limit for how long a creditor has the legal right to sue you to collect a debt. If this time has passed, the debt is considered "time-barred." While you may still owe the debt, they cannot win a lawsuit against you to collect it if you raise the SOL as a defense.
suggested_evidence: Proof of Date of First Delinquency

S2.name: SOL Revival Through Partial Payment
S2.description: A partial payment may have restarted the statute of limitations on a time-barred debt.
S2.why_it_matters: In many states, making a partial payment on a time-barred debt can restart the statute of limitations, giving collectors new legal power to sue. If a payment was recorded shortly before new collection activity began on an old debt, the consumer may have unknowingly revived the debt. This payment should be verified.
suggested_evidence: State SOL laws regarding debt revival

DU1.name: Potential Duplicate Reporting
DU1.description: The same debt appears to be reported multiple times by different furnishers.
DU1.why_it_matters: The same debt should not be reported as "Active" or having a "Balance" by multiple entities simultaneously. Usually, when a debt is sold, the original creditor must report a $0 balance. Duplicate reporting artificially inflates your debt and multiplies the negative impact on your credit score.
suggested_evidence: Notice of assignment or sale of debt

DU2.name: Same Debt Different Account Numbers
DU2.description: Multiple accounts with different numbers appear to reference the same original debt.
DU2.why_it_matters: Collectors sometimes report the same debt under different account numbers, either due to internal numbering changes or intentional obfuscation. This makes it harder for consumers to track and dispute debts, and can result in the same debt being counted multiple times in creditworthiness calculations.
suggested_evidence: Credit reports showing similar balances/dates across accounts
Original creditor name on each entry
Debt validation requests for each account

M1.name: Metro2 Integrity: DOFD vs Charge-Off Logic
M1.description: The relationship between DOFD and Charge-Off Date violates industry standards.
M1.why_it_matters: The Metro2 format used by furnishers requires that a charge-off date be logically consistent with the Date of First Delinquency (typically ~180 days). Discrepancies here prove the furnisher's internal records are disorganized or inaccurate.

M2.name: Metro2 Compliance: Balance on Sold/Transferred Debt
M2.description: A balance is being reported on an account marked as 'Sold' or 'Transferred'.
M2.why_it_matters: Under Metro2 standards, once a debt is sold or transferred, the original furnisher MUST report a $0 balance. Reporting a balance on a sold debt causes duplicate debt reporting and violates the FCRA requirement for accuracy.

K6.name: Forensic Clock Drift Detection
K6.description: The reporting clock appears to be based on the account open date rather than the delinquency date.
K6.why_it_matters: This is a sophisticated re-aging tactic where collectors 'drift' the reporting window by using the acquisition date as the starting point for the 7-year clock. This is a direct violation of FCRA ยง 605(c).

K7.name: Excessive Interest Violation
K7.description: The implied interest rate exceeds state legal caps for medical or judgment debt.
K7.why_it_matters: Collectors often apply high interest rates that exceed state-specific caps (usury laws). Reporting or collecting an illegal amount is a violation of the FDCPA and state consumer protection laws.

L1.name: Lexical Consistency Violation
L1.description: The reported account status contradicts the detailed payment history.
L1.why_it_matters: A credit report must be internally consistent. If an account is reported as 'Current' while showing lates in the history, it proves the furnisher is reporting inaccurate data, which is a violation of the FCRA.

BK1.name: Post-Bankruptcy Balance Reporting
BK1.description: Debt discharged in bankruptcy is reporting a balance greater than zero.
BK1.why_it_matters: A bankruptcy discharge order legally prohibits creditors from attempting to collect the debt. Reporting a balance on a discharged debt is a violation of the bankruptcy injunction and the FCRA's accuracy requirements.
suggested_evidence: Evidence of notice of discharge provided to creditor

J1.name: Judgment Statute of Limitations Expired
J1.description: A judgment is being reported beyond the legal reporting limit.
J1.why_it_matters: Judgments can generally only be reported for 7 years from the date of entry. Reporting a judgment beyond this period is a violation of the FCRA.
suggested_evidence: Court record showing judgment entry date
Evidence of judgment satisfaction or vacation

SL1.name: Student Loan Rehabilitation Inaccuracy
SL1.description: Student loan marked as 'rehabilitated' still shows delinquency or collection status.
SL1.why_it_matters: Under the Higher Education Act, once a student loan is successfully rehabilitated, the default marker MUST be removed from your credit history. Failing to do so prevents you from accessing new federal aid and harms your credit score illegally.
suggested_evidence: Payment history showing on-time rehabilitation payments

UC1.name: Usury Clock Drift Audit
UC1.description: Balance growth indicates an interest rate exceeding state usury caps.
UC1.why_it_matters: When collectors add interest to a debt, they must adhere to state usury laws. If the balance grows faster than the legal annual limit, they are overcharging you, which is a violation of the FDCPA and state law.

ZR1.name: Zombie Debt Resuscitation
ZR1.description: Debt appearing for the first time after the statute of limitations has expired.
ZR1.why_it_matters: Collectors often purchase 'debt portfolios' and report them as new accounts to trick consumers into paying. If the debt first appears on your credit report AFTER the legal time to sue has passed, it is often a sign of illegal resuscitation or re-aging.
suggested_evidence: Proof of true DOFD from original creditor
Evidence that the debt was first reported after SOL expiry

MD1.name: Medical Financial Assistance Screening Missing
MD1.description: Medical debt reported without required state-level financial assistance (Charity Care) screening.
MD1.why_it_matters: Several states (e.g., CA, WA, NY) require hospitals and providers to screen patients for financial assistance eligibility BEFORE referring the debt to collections. Failing to do so makes the collection action premature and potentially illegal under state consumer protection acts.
suggested_evidence: Evidence of income eligibility for charity care

MIL1.name: SCRA Interest Rate Violation
MIL1.description: Interest rate on debt exceeds 6% during a period of active military service.
MIL1.why_it_matters: The Servicemembers Civil Relief Act (SCRA) mandates that interest on any debt incurred before active duty must be capped at 6% during the period of military service. Exceeding this is a federal violation and can lead to significant statutory damages.
suggested_evidence: Military service records (DD214 or active duty orders)
Notice sent to creditor regarding military status

COT1.name: Systematic Re-assignment Pattern
COT1.description: The debt has been sold or transferred multiple times in a short period ('hot potato' debt).
COT1.why_it_matters: Frequent transfers of debt often lead to data corruption, lost chain of title, and inaccurate balance reporting. This is a common tactic used to mask the original DOFD and restart the collection clock illegally.
suggested_evidence: Prior credit reports showing different owners
Validation letters from each alleged owner

ST1.name: Stale Status Update Anomaly
ST1.description: Account is closed but receives frequent status updates or date refreshments.
ST1.why_it_matters: Once an account is closed and charged off, the 'Date Reported' should not be refreshed unless there is a material change. Frequent 'soft refreshes' on stale debt is a tactic used to keep the debt appearing 'new' to credit scoring algorithms.
suggested_evidence: Prior credit reports showing older reported dates

TB1.name: Treble Damage Risk Indicator
TB1.description: The combination of violations indicates a high potential for statutory treble damages under state law.
TB1.why_it_matters: Certain states (like Massachusetts under 93A) allow for triple (treble) damages if a business practice is found to be willfully deceptive or unfair. Combining interest violations with re-aging tactics often meets this threshold.
suggested_evidence: Multiple concurrent violations on a single tradeline
